{"Received":{"output":[{"Text":{"text":"Yes‚Äîlet‚Äôs lock in on ‚ÄúpCPU on veth + (optional) VFIO-bound NIC for transfer‚Äù as the primary path and push it forward.

Why the veth numbers are lower
- AF_PACKET vdev + veth runs entirely in the kernel path (extra copies, no offloads), so it‚Äôs perfect for pCPU behavior/metrics but not for raw throughput.
- Real NIC (enp‚Üíenx) with AF_PACKET vdev is faster (~86 MB/s TX; ~72 MB/s RX during the active window we saw).
- DPDK PMD (VFIO-bound NIC) is the true fast path for transfer; we‚Äôll keep that as a separate ‚Äúline-rate mode‚Äù once you confirm which PCI device(s) to bind.

What I‚Äôve done just now
- Added new pCPU ops and wired them through the RX CLIs:
  - crc32c checksum: --pcpu-op crc32c
  - counteq count reduction (counts bytes equal to imm8; aggregated result in checksum_out): --pcpu-op counteq --imm 0x00
- Expanded the veth-based sweep tool to include fnv, crc32c, counteq, xor, add; kept duration/align/streams modest so it completes quickly.
- Rebuilt DPDK TX/RX successfully.

Plan: pCPU-first roadmap
1) Cleanup and stability
   - Quiet veth delete noise (check-before-delete), pin timestamps and logs, add simple summaries.
   - Keep PVRT-required parsing with L2 skip to avoid martians.

2) v1 instruction set (done + next)
   - Done: fnv64, xor imm8, add imm8, crc32c, counteq imm8.
   - Next ops to add (data-reduction/pattern-leaning):
     - countgt imm8 (bytes > imm), countneq imm8
     - hist8 (256-bucket histogram; aggregated result in metrics or a side buffer)
     - rabin64 rolling checksum (content-defined chunking stepping stone)
     - bloom-hash (compute k-hash positions; good for membership filters)
   - Note: counteq/gt/neq and hist8 let us do meaningful reduction without a separate output ring yet.

3) v2 ‚Äúprogram‚Äù abstraction (make pCPU feel like a CPU)
   - Define a small program format (sequence of ops with imm/flags).
   - Runner: apply the sequence per-span in order (initially re-walking memory; later fuse/tiling).
   - Add basic ‚Äúregister-like‚Äù accumulators (R0..R3) in metrics for small per-program results.

4) Big sweeps
   - veth pCPU sweep: vary op, streams, align, desc-per-frame, duration; record pCPU_MBps, bytes_touched, desc_count, and any error counters into CSV.
   - real NIC sweep: same grid with enp‚Üíenx path for better transfer numbers.
   - PMD mode: once you tell me the PCI (e.g., 0000:65:00.0), I‚Äôll add a VFIO bind helper + PMD runs (separate file-prefix) and include in the sweep harness.

5) Pattern matching/data reduction
   - Start with byte-based predicates and hist8 to establish baseline reduction.

{"Received":{"output":[{"Text":{"text":"For a Threadripper (or any modern AMD HEDT) tuned for DPDK and local pCPU work, check/enable these BIOS settings:

Must‚Äëenable for VFIO/DPDK and isolation
- SVM (AMD‚ÄëV): enabled
- IOMMU/AMD‚ÄëVi: enabled
- SR‚ÄëIOV: enabled (only if you plan to use VFs; harmless to enable)
- ACS (PCIe Access Control Services): enable/auto if present; helps clean IOMMU groups on some boards
- Above 4G decoding / 64‚Äëbit BAR support: enabled
- Re‚Äësize BAR (ReBAR): optional; enable if stable (helps some GPUs, generally harmless)

Power/idle/boost (for stable polling cores)
- Global C‚Äëstates: disabled (keeps poll cores from deep idle latency spikes)
- CPPC / CPPC Preferred Cores: enabled (modern schedulers like it; optional if you isolate cores)
- PBO/Boost: enabled; but for polling cores you might cap or fix frequency if chasing determinism
- Typical Current Idle or equivalent: set to ‚ÄúTypical‚Äù (server‚Äëish) to avoid aggressive low‚Äëpower states

Memory and NUMA
- NUMA nodes per socket: leave default; verify Linux sees nodes (numactl --hardware)
- Memory interleaving: disabled unless you want flat single‚Äënode behavior (usually keep NUMA visible)
- XMP/DOCP: enable to get full memory bandwidth

PCIe and devices
- PCIe speed/width: force Gen4/Gen5 if stable for your slot/NIC (Auto is fine if it negotiates correctly)
- Onboard NIC options: disable unused controllers to clean up IRQ noise (optional)
- Thunderbolt/USB4: leave enabled if you rely on it; note TB hubs can introduce timing jitter for USB NICs

Boot/kernel alignment
- In Linux, pair with:
  - amd_iommu=on iommu=pt on kernel cmdline
  - Isolate poll cores (isolcpus=nohz,domain,managed_irq,‚Ä¶), rcu_nocbs on those cores
  - Hugepages (2M and/or 1G) reserved at boot for DPDK
  - CPU governor ‚Äúperformance‚Äù (or pin specific cores to performance)

After changing BIOS
- Verify in OS:
  - dmesg | egrep -i 'iommu|amd-vi'
  - cat /sys/kernel/iommu_groups/*/devices/* (clean groups)
  - cat /sys/devices/system/cpu/cpufreq/policy*/scaling_governor
  - cat /proc/meminfo | grep -i huge

If you want, I can also generate a small checklist script to validate these settings from Linux and print ‚ÄúOK/NOT OK‚Äù so you can run it after reboot."}}],"canceled":false}}

{"Received":{"output":[{"Text":{"text":"Totally fair to be confused. Here‚Äôs the clean mental model of what we‚Äôve been doing:

{"Received":{"output":[{"Text":{"text":"You‚Äôre thinking in exactly the right direction. For local pCPU, we can (and should) bypass both the kernel and DPDK entirely. Use shared memory + ring queues, pinned cores, and descriptor references into a hugepage blob. Only bring NICs (and their stacks) back when you actually need to hit the wire.

Three viable paths, from ‚Äúpure local‚Äù to ‚Äúhardware-assisted‚Äù

1) Pure local pCPU (no kernel, no DPDK, no NIC)
- What: In-process loopback ‚Äúports‚Äù implemented with shared memory SPSC/MPMC rings on hugepages, passing descriptor lists that reference offsets in the big blob (no payload copies).
- How:
  - Create N logical ports, each with M queues. Each queue is an SPSC ring in the hugepage region.
  - TX writes descriptor arrays (offset,len) describing spans in the blob; RX pops them and immediately calls pfs_pcpu_apply on the referenced spans.
  - Pin RX and TX threads to specific cores, keep C-states shallow, and prefetch spans.
- Why: Highest local throughput and lowest latency; you only move pointers and execute pCPU ops. No syscalls after setup, no kernel involvement, no DPDK.

2) Optional kernel-assisted ‚Äúuserspace rings‚Äù for NIC days (but not needed for local)
- AF_XDP native mode: zero-copy rings in userspace backed by kernel memory (works if the NIC/driver supports driver/native mode). Useful when you want a NIC without PMD/VFIO.
- AF_PACKET vdev (what we used): portable for testing, but it‚Äôs a copy path; good for validation, not for maximum throughput.

3) Hardware-kissing (only when you want wire speed)
- PMD/VFIO (DPDK hardware drivers): true kernel-bypass to hit line rate. Needs a supported NIC (e.g., Intel X710/XXV710/E810, Mellanox mlx5). This is the right track for transfer, not for pure local.
- Exposing NIC DMA memory via a kernel module is possible but vendor-specific and adds complexity you don‚Äôt need for local pCPU.

What I propose to build next (fast local loopback)
- shm-ports backend
  - A light ‚Äúport driver‚Äù with a shared metadata page and per-queue ring buffers in hugepages.
  - TX/RX CLIs mirroring our DPDK ones, but using shm rings: pfs_stream_shm_tx / pfs_stream_shm_rx.
  - Descriptors reference the existing hugepage blob. RX immediately runs pfs_pcpu_apply with your op program (fnv, crc32c, counteq/xor/add, upcoming hist8/gt/neq/etc.).
  - Same multi-port/multi-queue semantics and round-robin scheduling on a single core; add multi-core later.
- Program abstraction (pCPU feels like a CPU)
  - A tiny ‚Äúprogram‚Äù format (sequence of ops with imm/flags) and 2‚Äì4 accumulator ‚Äúregisters‚Äù exposed in metrics.
  - Start with a single pass per span; fuse ops and add SIMD later.

Why this matches your vision
- You get ‚Äúdaemon listener queues on one CPU‚Äù and multiple logical ‚Äúports‚Äù without any kernel or DPDK dependency.
- When you do want transfer: swap the backend to AF_XDP/AF_PACKET/PMD via a pluggable interface, but the pCPU execution stays identical.
- The NIC firmware path you‚Äôre envisioning (mapping DMA memory or running on-SMARTNIC) is a natural evolution of the same ring+descriptor model: replace the producer with a NIC DMA completion ring or a firmware queue.

{"Received":{"output":[{"Text":{"text":"Here‚Äôs the straight, no-BS summary with hard numbers, what worked great, what was meh, and a path to your pGigantoRing + GPU idea.

What worked really well (keep doing this)
- Pure-local pCPU (kernel-free) over shared memory rings
  - Tool: dev/wip/native/pfs_shm_ring_bench (producer/consumer SPSC ring on hugepages; descriptors reference spans in the blob; consumer applies pCPU ops in-place)
  - Run (2 threads, varint+arith, dpf=64, ring=2^16, align=64, duration=5s): avg ‚âà 321.9 MB/s effective bytes processed; 1.613 GB in 5.011 s
  - Why it‚Äôs great: zero kernel, zero DPDK‚Äîjust pointers and a tight CPU loop touching real data; perfect baseline for local pCPU throughput and op sweeps

- DPDK app scaffolding using AF_PACKET vdev (portable kernel-backed device)
  - TX-only on enp130s0 (Realtek r8169) for 10 s:
    - avg ‚âà 85.9‚Äì93.7 MB/s; total ‚âà 0.86‚Äì0.89 GB sent
  - End-to-end with enp (TX) ‚Üí enx (RX), Ethernet + PVRT header (L2 skip=14):
    - TX: ‚âà 86 MB/s; 859 MB in 10 s
    - RX: ‚âà 72 MB/s during the active window; total parsed ‚âà 797 MB
  - Why it‚Äôs good: lets us debug end-to-end framing, headers, and scheduling with no NIC binding; good transfer sanity checks

- Instruction set and plumbing
  - pCPU ops now: fnv64, crc32c, xor imm8, add imm8, counteq imm8
  - Available in RX paths (AF_XDP/DPDK) and in SHM bench (local fast path)
  - PVRT minimal header: bounds the varint region and carries align shift; RX requires PVRT when L2 skip is set (prevents ‚Äúmartians‚Äù)

- Windowed CPU microbench + scheduler bench
  - Native bench_exec: peak ‚âà 62M ops/s (tight ALU loop, no ring/IO)
  - pCPU scheduler bench: throughput_tasks_per_sec ‚âà 15,382 (threads=4, batch=4096, reps=8)

What was meh (and we fixed or learned from it)
- AF_XDP on USB NICs: fell back to XDP generic (skb) with copies‚Äîvery low TX throughput (on the order of 0.0‚Äì0.1 MB/s). Expected for that class of device/driver. Not a reflection on the architecture.
- DPDK two primaries conflict: had to use different --file-prefix for concurrent TX/RX processes; fixed by design.
- RX parsing and ‚Äúmartians‚Äù: before PVRT gating, RX could parse non-our frames; solved by requiring PVRT header with L2 skip and bounding varint by payload_len. Also prevented a one-off segfault in heavy noisy environments.
- Realtek RTL8168 has no DPDK PMD: we used net_af_packet vdev (kernel path). Fine for dev, not for line-rate PMD; when you add a supported NIC (Intel X710/XXV710/E810 or Mellanox mlx5), we can flip to PMD/VFIO.

Why you see different numbers across runs
- veth + AF_PACKET vdev: kernel copy path‚Äîstable for pCPU behavior, not meant for throughput (‚âà 0.7‚Äì1.1 MB/s in 5 s sweeps for these small configs).
- AF_PACKET on real NIC: better TX/RX (‚âà 86‚Äì94 MB/s TX; ‚âà 72 MB/s RX mid-burst), but still kernel-bound; good for end-to-end validation.
- Pure-local SHM rings: fastest local path right now (‚âà 322 MB/s on your current settings); the right place to optimize pCPU.

Where we are feature-wise
- Single-core multi-port/multi-queue RR scheduling implemented for the DPDK app path.
- Minimal protocol header + optional Ethernet framing in TX; strict header detection and bounded parse in RX.
- pCPU ops present in RX paths and the SHM local loop; counteq/CRC32C expands reduction + checksum choices.

Toward pGigantoRing + GPU (exactly your idea)
- The vision
  - A massive ring (or MPMC bundle of rings) in hugepage-pinned host memory (pGigantoRing) as the ‚ÄúCPU socket‚Äù
  - Producers write descriptor batches (offset,len) referencing the big blob; consumers are CPU cores and/or a GPU
  - The GPU consumes descriptor batches and applies op programs (counteq, hist8, crc32c, etc.) over coalesced spans, returning per-batch accumulators
  - CPU and GPU cooperate: CPU does control/scheduling/reduction; GPU crunches large, parallelizable ops across many spans

- Practical GPU plumbing on a laptop 5070
  - Use CUDA pinned host memory (cudaHostRegister or cudaHostAlloc) on the ring pages to enable zero-copy or fast H2D
  - Option A (simple): stage batches into a device buffer (cudaMemcpyAsync), launch kernels that walk spans, compute per-op accumulators, return a compact result (reduce on GPU or CPU)
  - Option B (pinned zero-copy): directly read pinned host memory from GPU kernels (UVA); coalesced access required; performance depends heavily on PCIe and access patterns
  - Structure: keep a control ring in pinned host memory; data blob is also pinned (or chunk-copied on demand); GPU reads descriptors from control ring, fetches spans in batches, emits R0..R3 accumulators
  - First GPU kernels to ship:
    - counteq imm8 (and countgt/neq): per-span byte predicate counters
    - hist8: 256-bucket histogram (use per-block shared-memory histograms + block-level reduction to avoid atomics)
    - crc32c (parallel chunking + combine or per-span atomic accumulate; simple per-span is fine initially)
  - Overlap: 2‚Äì3 CUDA streams to overlap H2D, kernel, D2H; batch sizes tuned to achieve full SM occupancy

- Why it‚Äôll help
  - GPU is very efficient at predicates/histograms/checksums when you batch many spans and align/pack them well
  - With a gigantic ring and a pinned blob, you amortize launch + transfer overhead across many spans, turning the GPU into a ‚ÄúpCPU ALU array‚Äù

- Longer-term (optional)
  - If/when you add a PMD NIC with GPUDirect RDMA, you can DMA directly into GPU buffers; for now, pure-local is enough

Recommended next steps
- Local pCPU fast path (now)
  - Expand shm-ports: multi-port, multi-queue on a single core; then multi-core scheduler
  - Add a pCPU ‚Äúprogram‚Äù abstraction (sequence of ops + a few accumulators), shared by CPU and GPU backends
  - Build a sweep to map best (op, align, dpf, batch) on local SHM (target: maximize pCPU_MBps and reduction per byte)

- GPU prototype (next)
  - Add a CUDA backend to the local shm runtime (control ring in pinned memory)
  - Implement counteq and hist8 kernels; measure pCPU_MBps-equivalent with a batch size study
  - Report speedups vs CPU-only pCPU for those ops

- Transfer track (parallel, optional)
  - Keep AF_PACKET runs for sanity; if/when you drop a DPDK-PMD NIC in the Threadripper box, I‚Äôll wire a PMD/VFIO sweep

TL;DR
- For local pCPU, the SHM ring path is already fast (‚âà 322 MB/s) and where we should focus for instruction design and sweeps.
- AF_PACKET vdev gave solid real-NIC TX/RX numbers (‚âà 86‚Äì94 MB/s TX; ‚âà 72 MB/s RX mid-burst), good for end-to-end testing.
- AF_XDP on USB NICs was slow (fallback path)‚Äînot a blocker for the architecture.
- pGigantoRing + GPU is the right next step: big pinned rings, batched spans, GPU kernels for counteq/hist8/crc32c, return accumulators‚ÄîGPU becomes a pCPU ALU array.

If you want, I‚Äôll:
- Expand the local shm-ports into multi-port/multi-queue (single core), add a ‚Äúprogram‚Äù runner, and add a sweep target.
- Start a small CUDA module (counteq + hist8) and a harness that pulls descriptor batches from pGigantoRing and prints MB/s plus reduction."}}],"canceled":false}}

{"Received":{"output":[{"Text":{"text":"Short answer
- This SHM sweep wasn‚Äôt the ‚Äútiny contiguous 80B‚Äù workload where we nuked the CPU with ~17√ó. It‚Äôs randomized spans (varint+arith), so you see ~1.6‚Äì1.7√ó CPUpwn at best.
- To recreate the ‚Äúpwn the CPU‚Äù conditions: force contiguity, keep segments small (‚âà80B), coalesce aggressively, keep the working set hot (L1/L2), and minimize per-span decode overhead. We can absolutely do that in the SHM runner.

What‚Äôs different vs the 17√ó ‚ÄúMax‚ÄëWin‚Äù runs
- Workload shape
  - Max‚ÄëWin: many tiny contiguous segments (‚âà80B), high coalescing ‚Üí super-hot cache, minimal deltas, tiny decode, tiny TLB churn
  - Current SHM sweep: randomized offsets with varint decode ‚Üí more metadata per byte, poorer locality, more cache/TLB churn
- Baseline definition
  - Max‚ÄëWin used a specific CPU baseline (dumb vs measured variants) and a windowed reconstructor that coalesced mercilessly
  - SHM CPUpwn baseline is a ‚Äútouch baseline‚Äù in the same ring topology (pcpu=0) for fair apples-to-apples local comparison

Your fresh numbers (arithmetic mode, SHM rings, 2 threads)
- Best configs (3 s windows):
  - xor imm=0x5A, align=256, dpf=128, queues=2 ‚Üí avg‚âà 642.7 MB/s, CPU baseline‚âà 379.5 MB/s, CPUpwn‚âà 1.69√ó
  - add imm=0x05, align=256, dpf=64, queues=2 ‚Üí avg‚âà 642.3 MB/s, CPU‚âà 378.5 MB/s, CPUpwn‚âà 1.70√ó
  - align=64 configs land ‚âà 1.33‚Äì1.36√ó CPUpwn
- Earlier ‚ÄúSHM single run‚Äù (5 s) landed ‚âà 322‚Äì353 MB/s avg; the sweep found better shapes (align=256, queues=2).

How to recreate (and amplify) the 17√ó conditions locally
- Shape spans for contiguous hot regions
  - Add generation modes: contig vs scatter, with segment length controls
    - Example knobs I can add: --mode contig|scatter, --seg-len 80, --coalesce-gap 64, --stride 0 (ascending), --reuse-frames 1
  - Force coalescing (merge adjacent spans within a small gap)
  - Keep alignment modest (64‚Äì128) to maximize cache reuse (align=256 helped here by simplifying decode; we‚Äôll test both)
- Minimize per-span overhead
  - Fixed descriptor path (arith=0) for compute-only sweeps (avoids varint decode); use varint only when we measure encoding/streaming
  - Reuse pre-encoded frames (‚Äìreuse-frames) to remove producer overhead and isolate consumer/pCPU throughput
  - Prefetch (‚Äìprefetch-dist, e.g., 2‚Äì4 spans ahead)
- Keep the working set hot
  - Small window sizes (dpf=32‚Äì64) when contig; or target total bytes per window (e.g., 80B√óN)
  - Pin threads, performance governor, 1‚Äì2 rings (less queue contention), hugepages locked

If you want, I‚Äôll add these flags to pfs_shm_ring_bench so we can run:
- SHM ‚Äúcontig 80B‚Äù shape (compute-only):
  - just run-shm-ring-bench threads=2 arith=0 align=64 dpf=64 ports=1 queues=1 op=counteq imm=0 prog="counteq:0,crc32c" [plus new --mode contig --seg-len 80 --coalesce-gap 64 --reuse-frames 1]
- SHM ‚Äúvarint+arith 80B‚Äù shape (end-to-end-ish):
  - same but arith=1 vstream=1; compare pCPU vs touch baseline for CPUpwn

LLVM optimizations
- SHM runner (pfs_pcpu.c) today is hand-written C loops (compiled -O3 -march=native). No LLVM IR fusion yet.
- Two LLVM directions we can add:
  - IR pipeline (you already have IR executor): we can run opt -O3/SLP/vectorize passes on IR kernels and time them; good for standalone compute.
  - pCPU program JIT: take a short program (e.g., counteq‚Üíhist8‚Üícrc32c), generate a fused LLVM function at runtime (ORC JIT), unroll/auto-vectorize, and call that in the consumer loop. That kills dispatch overhead and lets LLVM fuse loops and prefetch.
- Plus: SIMD intrinsics immediately for XOR/ADD and CRC32C (use hardware crc32 where available) as a quick boost without JIT.

Proposed next steps (I can code this)
- Add ‚Äúcontig‚Äù workload mode to SHM runner:
  - Flags: --mode contig|scatter, --seg-len N (default 80), --coalesce-gap N, --reuse-frames 1|0, --prefetch-dist N
  - Make producer generate ascending segments and coalesce; optional frame reuse (producer once, then loop)
- Add a SHM ‚Äúcontig sweep‚Äù and compute CPUpwn
  - Sweep seg_len around 80; dpf in {32,64,128}; align in {64,128,256}; queues in {1,2}; CPUpwn vs touch baseline
  - Goal: find a shape that approaches the prior ~17√ó (note: that 17√ó was in the blueprint reconstructor domain with its own baseline; we‚Äôll document differences)
- Start LLVM path
  - Option A (quick): add SIMD intrinsics for XOR/ADD and crc32 (hardware) in pfs_pcpu.c with a -DUSE_SIMD flag
  - Option B (bigger): scaffold an ORC JIT to fuse a small program of ops into one loop

CUDA
- I‚Äôll scaffold a CUDA backend next:
  - Pinned control ring + blob
  - Kernels for counteq imm8 and hist8 (shared-memory per-block), then crc32c
  - Batched descriptors, overlapped H2D/kernels/D2H, aggregated R0..R3 results
  - Add GPUpwn against the same CPU touch baseline (pcpu=0) and the SHM pCPU path

If you want me to proceed, I‚Äôll:
- Implement SHM contig mode + the new flags
- Run a ‚Äúcontig 80B‚Äù sweep and report CPUpwn
- Start the CUDA skeleton and build harness + Just targets"}}],"canceled":false}}

{"Received":{"output":[{"Text":{"text":"Great progress. Given your hardware and goals, I recommend starting with DPDK parameter sweeps first, then attempt AF_XDP concurrency as a follow-up. Here‚Äôs why and how for both paths.

Recommendation
- Start with DPDK sweeps: This isolates your userspace pipeline (rings, bursts, streams, pCPU) from AF_XDP driver/stack variability and will quickly show where TX is getting throttled. You already have the PVRT+L2-skip requirement in place, so keep that invariant as you sweep.
- Then try AF_XDP concurrently: Do this to compare kernel paths (AF_PACKET vs AF_XDP). On USB ‚Äúenx‚Äù NICs you‚Äôll likely be limited to SKB/generic mode (no zero-copy), so absolute numbers may not jump, but it‚Äôs still useful to characterize latency and CPU cost.

DPDK sweeps (quick plan)
- Keep: PVRT header on, L2 skip=14 on RX (as you implemented).
- Vary:
  - queues per side: 1, 2, 4
  - streams: 1, 2, 4, 8
  - burst/desc-per-frame (dpf): 16, 32, 64, 128
  - ring size (pow2): 14, 16, 18
  - alignment: 64, 128
  - threads: 2, 3, 4 (consider pinning RX/TX/pCPU)
  - pCPU op: off vs fnv vs crc32c vs counteq:0x00/0xFF (to track CPUpwn vs baseline)
- Suggested runs (examples; adapt to your binary/flags):
  - RX: bind to one core group, AF_PACKET vdev on first enx, l2skip=14, pvrt=on, queues={1,2,4}
  - TX: bind to another core group, AF_PACKET vdev on second enx, pvrt=on, duration=10s, streams={1,2,4,8}, dpf={32,64,128}
- Notes:
  - If TX remains ~0.2 MB/s irrespective of streams/queues/dpf, it points to a backpressure or config bottleneck (e.g., small mempool, small txq, or pacing in the TX loop).
  - Pin cores (taskset or EAL -l) so RX/TX don‚Äôt contend.
  - Log RX/TX summary and pCPU stats per run to a CSV so you can compute CPUpwn (pcpu on/off under identical params).

AF_XDP concurrent run (follow-up)
- Preflight:
  - ethtool -i enxX; ethtool -k enxX | grep -i xdp (USB NICs usually support generic XDP, not zero-copy)
  - ulimit -l unlimited (locked memory)
  - sysctl: consider bumping net.core.rmem_max/wmem_max if your AF_XDP app benefits
- Build:
  - just build-net-pfs-stream-afxdp
- Run (examples; adjust to your actual run targets/flags):
  - sudo -E just run-pfs-stream-afxdp-rx IFACE=enxRX QUEUES=1 MODE=skb ZC=0 L2_SKIP=14 PVRT=1
  - sudo -E just run-pfs-stream-afxdp-tx IFACE=enxTX DURATION=10 STREAMS=1 PVRT=1
  - Then sweep QUEUES={1,2}, STREAMS={1,2,4}, and compare to the AF_PACKET vdev results.
- Keep PVRT header enabled to match your RX filter logic with L2 skip.

If you want, I can kick off the DPDK sweeps now (5‚Äì10 second runs over a small grid to start) and report a table with RX/TX MB/s, drops, and CPUpwn. Then we‚Äôll attempt the AF_XDP concurrent pair and compare. Which path do you want me to execute first?"}}],"canceled":false}}
